title: 110_hr1944
content: The Act titled "Veterans Traumatic Brain Injury Treatment Act of 2007" introduces screening, rehabilitation, and treatment for traumatic brain injury under a new subchapter in Chapter 17 of title 38, United States Code. The Act establishes a screening program for veterans eligible for medical care to screen for traumatic brain injury symptoms. The Secretary must submit an annual report on the number of veterans screened, prevalence of symptoms, and recommendations for care. Additionally, a comprehensive program for long-term traumatic brain injury rehabilitation will be developed and implemented. The Secretary will develop a comprehensive program for long-term traumatic brain injury rehabilitation, including residential, community, and home-based components. The program will be carried out in four geographically dispersed polytrauma network sites. Eligibility criteria include serving in combat operations after the Persian Gulf War and being diagnosed with moderate to severe symptoms. The Secretary will establish traumatic brain injury transition offices at Department polytrauma network sites to coordinate health care. A report on the program's operation, number of veterans served, and annual cost will be submitted annually to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs. The Secretary will establish traumatic brain injury transition offices at Department polytrauma network sites to coordinate health care and services for veterans with moderate to severe traumatic brain injuries. These offices can arrange for health care through cooperative agreements with public or private entities. Additionally, a Traumatic Brain Injury Veterans' Health Registry will be established to maintain information on affected individuals. The Traumatic Brain Injury Veterans' Health Registry will contain the names of veterans with symptoms of traumatic brain injury from Operation Enduring Freedom or Operation Iraqi Freedom who seek care or file compensation claims. It will also include relevant medical data with permission from the individuals. The Traumatic Brain Injury Veterans' Health Registry will include names of veterans with symptoms of traumatic brain injury from Operation Enduring Freedom or Operation Iraqi Freedom. The Secretary may include other relevant information if permission is granted or if the individual is deceased. Individuals listed will be notified of significant research developments on the health consequences of military service in these theaters of operations. Subchapter IX of title 38, United States Code, includes screening, rehabilitation, transition offices, and a registry for traumatic brain injuries. The Secretary must implement these requirements within 180 days of the enactment of the Act.
